;;T;;机器超越人类的想法;长期以来一直是科幻小说的主题。过去十年来，人工智能 (;AI;) 程序的快速进步让一些专家得出结论：科幻小说可能很快就会成为事实。 3月19日;黄仁勋;，首席执行官全球最大的计算机芯片制造商和第三大最有价值的上市公司英伟达表示，他相信今天的模型可以在五年内发展到所谓的通用人工智能（;AGI;）。 ;AGI;到底是什么——如何判断它何时到来？

;

;黄先生的话值得采纳半信半疑：由于 ;对其高科技芯片的需求不断增长;，这些芯片用于训练;AI;模型。因此，推广;AI;对商业有利。但黄先生确实对他认为构成<小>;AGI;的内容给出了明确的定义：一个在某些测试中比大多数人好8%的程序，例如律师资格考试或逻辑测验。< /p>;

;
;
;
;
;
;

;该提案是一长串定义中的最新提案。 20 世纪 50 年代，英国数学家艾伦·图灵 (Alan Turing) 表示，与实现了;AGI;的模型交谈与与人类交谈没有什么区别。可以说是最先进的;大型语言模型;已经通过了图灵测试。但近年来，科技领导者提出了一系列新的定义，从而改变了目标。 ;穆斯塔法·苏莱曼; 是人工智能研究公司 DeepMind 的联合创始人，也是微软新成立的人工智能部门的首席执行官，他认为，当模型获得 10 万美元，并在没有指示的情况下将其变成 100 万美元。 （苏莱曼先生是《经济学人》母公司的董事会成员。）苹果公司联合创始人史蒂夫·沃兹尼亚克 (Steve Wozniak) 对 ;AGI; 有着更为平淡的愿景：一台机器可以进入普通家庭并煮一杯咖啡。

;

;一些研究人员完全拒绝 ;AGI; 的概念。伦敦国王学院的迈克·库克表示，这个词没有科学依据，而且对不同的人有不同的含义。剑桥大学的哈里·劳 (Harry Law) 承认，很少有通用人工智能的定义能引起共识，但大多数定义都是基于这样的想法：一种模型可以在大多数任务上超越人类——无论是煮咖啡还是赚数百万美元。一月份，DeepMind 的研究人员提出了 ;AGI; 的六个级别，按照模型可以超越的熟练成年人的比例进行排名：他们表示该技术仅达到了最低水平，;AI; >; 等于或略优于 ;非熟练人类;。

;

;当我们达到 ;AGI; 时会发生什么的问题困扰着一些人研究人员。 Eliezer Yudkowsky 是一名计算机科学家，他对人工智能的研究已经有 20 年之久，他担心，当人们认识到模型已经;变得有知觉;，阻止它们就太晚了，人类将被奴役。但很少有研究人员同意他的观点。大多数人认为 ;AI; 只是简单地遵循人类输入，而且往往效果不佳。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;对于 ;AGI 的构成可能尚未达成共识;——但法庭上很快就会就定义达成一致。作为;诉讼的一部分; 埃隆·马斯克 (Elon Musk) 在 2 月份向他共同创立的 OpenAI 公司提起诉讼，要求加州法院裁定该公司的 ;GPT-4; 模型是否显示出 ;AGI; 的迹象。马斯克声称，如果确实如此，OpenAI 就违背了其只授权前;AGI;技术的创立原则。该公司否认曾这样做。马斯克正在通过他的律师寻求陪审团审判。如果他的愿望得到满足，少数非专家就可以解决一个困扰人工智能专家数十年的问题。 ;■;

;;F;;OOD IS SCARCE; in Gaza.据慈善机构救助儿童会称，许多居民正在街上吃树叶并寻找残羹剩饭。 Since the outbreak of war between Israel and Hamas, deliveries of food to the strip have been insufficient. Evidently, neither Israel nor Hamas considers getting food to the starving to be a priority. Israel insists it is not obstructing aid lorries. But the situation is so bad that America and others have begun air-dropping food into Gaza. America is also planning to build a pier to allow faster deliveries by sea.

;

;On March 18th the Integrated Food Security Phase Classification (;IPC;), a UN-backed initiative responsible for a scale that measures hunger, said that 30% of Gaza's population is experiencing ;catastrophic food insecurity;.它能够分析 95% 的人口（约 210 万人），并得出结论：没有人“粮食安全”。 Since it was established 20 years ago the ;IPC ;has declared only two famines: in Somalia in 2011, and in South Sudan in 2017. Unless there is a ceasefire and faster supplies of aid, the ;IPC ;believes it will have grounds to declare a third in Gaza's northern governates by May, and in southern Gaza by July. What exactly constitutes a famine?

;;
;

;;;Read all our coverage of the war between Israel and Hamas;;

;
;

;Famine has a technical definition, detailed in a 125-page manual. The ;IPC ;scale places individual households into one of five categories of food insecurity, ranging from “minimal”, meaning a household can meet its basic needs, to “famine”. In order to classify a household as experiencing famine, the ;UN; must see evidence of starvation or extreme malnutrition.要将整个地区纳入该类别，至少 20% 的家庭必须处于第五阶段。还有其他标准：每万人每天因饥饿而死亡的人数必须高于两人。 For children younger than five, who are most vulnerable to food shortages, it must be higher than four.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;How does the ;IPC; make its assessments? Any country or partner of the ;IPC ;can trigger a formal review if it suspects that famine is happening in a given place. When that happens, a group of independent humanitarian organisations are tasked with collecting data. This usually means ;UN ;agencies such as the World Food Programme and ;UNICEF ;going house to house, weighing children and asking about food intake and deaths.

;

;But the conditions in Gaza made this impossible, obliging the ;IPC ;to rely on other data. It turned to ;UNOSAT;, the; UN;'s Satellite Centre, which analysed images of agricultural land; and the World Food Programme, which questioned shop owners over the phone about shortages. An independent group of security, nutrition and mortality experts reviewed the evidence they gathered. On this basis, the ;IPC ;concluded that Gaza is currently in phase four, a food “emergency”—but warned that parts of the north may already have tipped into famine (see chart).

;;
;;
;

;Interpreting data is difficult: most hunger-related deaths result from a combination of malnutrition and disease. In war-torn places like Gaza, collecting it is hard in the first place. In parts of the strip information is patchy. In the north, where 300,000 people are still living, only a handful of hospitals and clinics are operating, which limits the supply of health data. It is hard to reach families on the phone when they have little access to ;electricity; or ;mobile signals;.

;

;But the evidence that the ;IPC ;has gathered paints a bleak picture. It found that Israeli strikes had damaged 60% of Gaza's farmland by January and 56% of water facilities by February. The ;UN;'s Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs found that “severely restricted” ;aid deliveries; were not enough to sustain the population. It estimated that less than 5% of food trucks entering the strip reached the north in the month to March 18th. The ;IPC;'s report helped to galvanise the ;UN ;Security Council, which on March 25th called for an immediate ceasefire. Without one, people in Gaza will continue to starve.;■;

On March 7th Russian security services said they had foiled an attack by Islamic State (;IS;), a jihadist outfit, on a synagogue in Moscow.因此，在番红花城袭击发生数小时后，该组织声称对此事负责，也就不足为奇了。 3 月 25 日，四名据称来自塔吉克斯坦的嫌疑人出庭。 American officials believe they are part of the Islamic State Khorasan Province (;ISKP;). What is this outfit, and what threat does it pose?

;

;;ISKP; is the Central Asian offshoot of ;IS;, the group that established a “caliphate” in Iraq and Syria in 2014. (;IS; had ;lost most of the land it controlled there; by 2018. Several other offshoots are active in ;Africa; and elsewhere.) Khorasan is a historical area that takes in parts of Iran, Afghanistan and other Central Asian countries (see map). Based mainly in northern and eastern Afghanistan, ;ISKP; is an implacable enemy of the Taliban, an Islamist group that retook control of the country after the departure of American troops in August 2021. ;ISKP; portrays the Taliban as sell-outs for signing a deal with America and co-operating with its withdrawal. It also frequently criticises Tajikistan's dictator, Emomali Rahmon, an ally of Russia's president, Vladimir Putin, in messaging groups because he bans ;outward displays of Islamic belief;.

;;
;;
;

;;ISKP; seems to have been established in 2014. It attracted disaffected members of the Pakistani Taliban as well as Afghan members, whose regime had been routed by American-backed forces by 2003. The group, which follows Sunni Islam, prides itself on being even less forgiving of non-believers and other Islamic groups—including followers of Shia Islam, the second-largest branch of the faith after Sunnism.它声称对 2019 年至 2021 年间发生的多起阿富汗清真寺、葬礼和学校袭击事件负责。 During America's withdrawal from the country it carried out a ;suicide-bombing at Kabul airport;, killing more than 100 people, including 13 American soldiers.

;Since July 2022 Afghanistan's rulers have ordered repeated raids on the group's hideouts. The number of successful attacks by ;ISKP; in the country has fallen.
